abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Investment Guarantee
            Facility Project for Afghanistan were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            Afghanistan's environment is challenging for Foreign
            Direct Investment (FDI), in particular the worsening
            security environment and governance. Availability of
            political risk guarantee is not enough to mitigate the
            concerns of foreign investors. Without minimum peace and
            security, long-term investments are difficult to attract.
            The Afghanistan Investment Guarantee Facility (AIGF)
            marketing activities will have been further improved by
            hiring a local marketing representative, familiar with local
            investment and business environment as well as political
            risk insurance products. The previous operation of
            Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) in Bosnia
            and Herzegovina highlighted the importance of having a
            full-time representative working on the ground to increase
            awareness and liaise with investors on a continuing basis;
            once a special representative was placed in-country, there
            was a steady flow of inquiries from foreign investors for
            guarantees. In addition, local representative can help MIGA
            staff in headquarters to better understand the risks
            involved in the country since more detailed information can
            be provided. This greatly helps in the management of risks
            in a high-risk environment.
